newsitem.title: USA: SEC seeks comments on tax-exempt money fund rules.
newsitem.headline: SEC seeks comments on tax-exempt money fund rules.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday requested public comment on a series of proposed revisions to its rule governing tax-exempt money market funds.
Comments on revisions to SEC's Rule 2a-7 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 are due January 24, according to the draft rules.
The SEC voted in late March 1996 to tighten standards for the quality and diversity of bonds held by tax-exempt money market funds.
But the commission on August 14 temporarily postponed the effective date of the new rules, which was originally set for October 3, so that it could consider some "technical" changes.

An SEC official said last week that the proposed revisions will not affect the major rule changes affecting tax-exempt money funds that the SEC made in March. "Nothing we're doing here will affect any of those decisions," the official said.
One technical revision, he said, would "clarify" the way that guarantees and demand features are treated under Rule 2a-7.
"To the extent that there was confusion as to whether guarantees and unconditional demand features were being treated the same way for various purposes, this should clear this up," he said.
The SEC voted March 21 to bar funds that invest in tax-exempt securities nationwide from investing more than five percent of their assets in the securities of a single issuer.
The move was designed to prevent a tax-exempt fund from putting "all its eggs in one basket," the SEC said.

But because of the limited supply of high-quality tax-exempt securities in some states, funds that invest only in the bonds of single states must "be diversified at the five-percent level, but only as to 75 percent of their assets," the SEC said.
Single state funds must disclose in prospectuses that there are increased risks associated with their policy of concentrating on the bonds of one state.
